statement.text: Distal origin bypass uses a more distal arterial inflow source (such as popliteal artery) rather than femoral artery, creating a shorter bypass that conserves conduit and may improve patency for patients with isolated tibial disease.

explanation.intuition: If the highway is clear until the last exit (popliteal) but the local roads (tibials) are blocked, why build a bypass from the highway entrance (femoral)? Starting closer to the blockage uses less vein and puts less conduit at risk.
explanation.key_insight: Shorter bypasses have fewer anastomoses to fail and conserve conduit for future procedures. When inflow is adequate (popliteal ABI >0.8, triphasic Doppler), distal origin bypass is a reasonable strategy.
explanation.technical_details: Inflow assessment: measure popliteal pressure, should have <15mmHg gradient from femoral. Sources: above-knee popliteal, below-knee popliteal, tibioperoneal trunk. Configurations: pop-tibial, pop-pedal. Advantages: conserves vein, shorter OR time, fewer complications. Concerns: may sacrifice future options if inflow deteriorates. Patency: comparable to fem-tibial when appropriate selection.

clinical_features.concept: Use most distal adequate inflow source
clinical_features.considerations: May limit future options if proximal disease progresses

clinical_pearls: Confirm adequate inflow with popliteal pressure measurement
Conserves conduit for potential future procedures
